content.text: Welcome! In this lesson, you'll learn how to order your first coffee in a Dutch coffee shop, or 'koffietentje'.

data.tip: The Dutch 'g' is a soft, throaty sound, like clearing your throat gently. Practice by saying 'goedemorgen'.

content.text: Adding 'graag' (gladly) to 'ik wil' (I want) makes your request polite, similar to saying 'I would like...' instead of 'I want...'.

content.title: Greeting the Barista
content.setting: You've reached the counter at a cozy Dutch coffee shop. The barista greets you.

conversation_flow.title: Say that you would like something

content.text: 'Koffie verkeerd' literally means 'wrong coffee' because it has more milk than coffee. It's the Dutch version of a café au lait.
Get ready! The barista will ask 'hier opdrinken of meenemen?' which means 'For here or to go?'.

content.title: Placing Your Order
content.setting: The barista is waiting for your order.

conversation_flow.title: Say you'll have it 'for here'
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Een koffie verkeerd. Wil je die hier opdrinken of meenemen?

content.text: In the Netherlands, 'pinnen' is a very common verb that means 'to pay with a debit card'.
The word 'alsjeblieft' is very useful. It means 'please' when you ask for something, and 'here you go' when you give or receive something.

content.title: Paying for Your Coffee
content.setting: You've ordered your drink, now it's time to pay.

conversation_flow.title: Say you can pay by card
